data.author: Aristotle
data.en: Education is an ornament in prosperity and a refuge in adversity.

data.author: Aristotle
data.en: Politicians also have no leisure, because they are always aiming at something beyond political life itself, power and glory, or happiness.

data.author: Aristotle
data.en: Well begun is half done.

data.author: Aristotle
data.en: The virtue of justice consists in moderation, as regulated by wisdom.

data.author: Aristotle
data.en: The poet, being an imitator like a painter or any other artist, must of necessity imitate one of three objects - things as they were or are, things as they are said or thought to be, or things as they ought to be. The vehicle of expression is language - either current terms or, it may be, rare words or metaphors.

data.author: Aristotle
data.en: In all things of nature there is something of the marvelous.

data.author: Aristotle
data.en: It is the mark of an educated mind to be able to entertain a thought without accepting it.

data.author: Aristotle
data.en: There was never a genius without a tincture of madness.

data.author: Aristotle
data.en: The aim of the wise is not to secure pleasure, but to avoid pain.

data.author: Aristotle
data.en: Moral excellence comes about as a result of habit. We become just by doing just acts, temperate by doing temperate acts, brave by doing brave acts.

data.author: Aristotle
data.en: The most perfect political community is one in which the middle class is in control, and outnumbers both of the other classes.

data.author: Aristotle
data.en: Man is the only animal capable of reasoning, though many others possess the faculty of memory and instruction in common with him.

data.author: Aristotle
data.en: The state comes into existence for the sake of life and continues to exist for the sake of good life.

data.author: Aristotle
data.en: Persuasion is clearly a sort of demonstration, since we are most fully persuaded when we consider a thing to have been demonstrated.

data.author: Aristotle
data.en: It is unbecoming for young men to utter maxims.

data.author: Aristotle
data.en: Rhetoric may be defined as the faculty of observing in any given case the available means of persuasion. This is not a function of any other art.

data.author: Aristotle
data.en: In a democracy the poor will have more power than the rich, because there are more of them, and the will of the majority is supreme.

data.author: Aristotle
data.en: What it lies in our power to do, it lies in our power not to do.

data.author: Aristotle
data.en: You will never do anything in this world without courage. It is the greatest quality of the mind next to honor.

data.author: Aristotle
data.en: The generality of men are naturally apt to be swayed by fear rather than reverence, and to refrain from evil rather because of the punishment that it brings than because of its own foulness.

data.author: Aristotle
data.en: All virtue is summed up in dealing justly.

data.author: Aristotle
data.en: Plato is dear to me, but dearer still is truth.

data.author: Aristotle
data.en: Bashfulness is an ornament to youth, but a reproach to old age.

data.author: Aristotle
data.en: Democracy arises out of the notion that those who are equal in any respect are equal in all respects; because men are equally free, they claim to be absolutely equal.

data.author: Aristotle
data.en: The beginning of reform is not so much to equalize property as to train the noble sort of natures not to desire more, and to prevent the lower from getting more.

data.author: Aristotle
data.en: No excellent soul is exempt from a mixture of madness.

data.author: Aristotle
data.en: Thou wilt find rest from vain fancies if thou doest every act in life as though it were thy last.

data.author: Aristotle
data.en: Anybody can become angry - that is easy, but to be angry with the right person and to the right degree and at the right time and for the right purpose, and in the right way - that is not within everybody's power and is not easy.

data.author: Aristotle
data.en: What the statesman is most anxious to produce is a certain moral character in his fellow citizens, namely a disposition to virtue and the performance of virtuous actions.

data.author: Aristotle
data.en: Perfect friendship is the friendship of men who are good, and alike in excellence; for these wish well alike to each other qua good, and they are good in themselves.

data.author: Aristotle
data.en: Love is composed of a single soul inhabiting two bodies.

data.author: Aristotle
data.en: The ideal man bears the accidents of life with dignity and grace, making the best of circumstances.

data.author: Aristotle
data.en: The true and the approximately true are apprehended by the same faculty; it may also be noted that men have a sufficient natural instinct for what is true, and usually do arrive at the truth. Hence the man who makes a good guess at truth is likely to make a good guess at probabilities.

data.author: Aristotle
data.en: Bad men are full of repentance.

data.author: Aristotle
data.en: In constructing the plot and working it out with the proper diction, the poet should place the scene, as far as possible, before his eyes. In this way, seeing everything with the utmost vividness, as if he were a spectator of the action, he will discover what is in keeping with it, and be most unlikely to overlook inconsistencies.

data.author: Aristotle
data.en: No one loves the man whom he fears.

data.author: Aristotle
data.en: The whole is more than the sum of its parts.

data.author: Aristotle
data.en: There is no great genius without some touch of madness.

data.author: Aristotle
data.en: If one way be better than another, that you may be sure is nature's way.

data.author: Aristotle
data.en: It is not once nor twice but times without number that the same ideas make their appearance in the world.

data.author: Aristotle
data.en: Men create gods after their own image, not only with regard to their form but with regard to their mode of life.

data.author: Aristotle
data.en: The end of labor is to gain leisure.

data.author: Aristotle
data.en: Some animals are cunning and evil-disposed, as the fox; others, as the dog, are fierce, friendly, and fawning. Some are gentle and easily tamed, as the elephant; some are susceptible of shame, and watchful, as the goose. Some are jealous and fond of ornament, as the peacock.

data.author: Aristotle
data.en: Some kinds of animals burrow in the ground; others do not. Some animals are nocturnal, as the owl and the bat; others use the hours of daylight. There are tame animals and wild animals. Man and the mule are always tame; the leopard and the wolf are invariably wild, and others, as the elephant, are easily tamed.

data.author: Aristotle
data.en: Men acquire a particular quality by constantly acting in a particular way.

data.author: Aristotle
data.en: Change in all things is sweet.

data.author: Aristotle
data.en: The roots of education are bitter, but the fruit is sweet.

data.author: Aristotle
data.en: The aim of art is to represent not the outward appearance of things, but their inward significance.

data.author: Aristotle
data.en: Friendship is essentially a partnership.

data.author: Aristotle
data.en: Those that know, do. Those that understand, teach.

data.author: Aristotle
data.en: Long-lived persons have one or two lines which extend through the whole hand; short-lived persons have two lines not extending through the whole hand.

data.author: Aristotle
data.en: A tragedy is a representation of an action that is whole and complete and of a certain magnitude. A whole is what has a beginning and middle and end.

data.author: Aristotle
data.en: Good habits formed at youth make all the difference.

data.author: Aristotle
data.en: Homer has taught all other poets the art of telling lies skillfully.

data.author: Aristotle
data.en: A constitution is the arrangement of magistracies in a state.

data.author: Aristotle
data.en: The secret to humor is surprise.

data.author: Aristotle
data.en: The one exclusive sign of thorough knowledge is the power of teaching.

data.author: Aristotle
data.en: Our judgments when we are pleased and friendly are not the same as when we are pained and hostile.

data.author: Aristotle
data.en: In poverty and other misfortunes of life, true friends are a sure refuge. The young they keep out of mischief; to the old they are a comfort and aid in their weakness, and those in the prime of life they incite to noble deeds.

data.author: Aristotle
data.en: A friend to all is a friend to none.

data.author: Aristotle
data.en: Courage is the first of human qualities because it is the quality which guarantees the others.

data.author: Aristotle
data.en: Whosoever is delighted in solitude is either a wild beast or a god.

data.author: Aristotle
data.en: In making a speech one must study three points: first, the means of producing persuasion; second, the language; third the proper arrangement of the various parts of the speech.

data.author: Aristotle
data.en: Inferiors revolt in order that they may be equal, and equals that they may be superior. Such is the state of mind which creates revolutions.

data.author: Aristotle
data.en: At his best, man is the noblest of all animals; separated from law and justice he is the worst.

data.author: Aristotle
data.en: The educated differ from the uneducated as much as the living from the dead.

data.author: Aristotle
data.en: He who hath many friends hath none.

data.author: Aristotle
data.en: Most people would rather give than get affection.

data.author: Aristotle
data.en: All paid jobs absorb and degrade the mind.

data.author: Aristotle
data.en: The energy of the mind is the essence of life.

data.author: Aristotle
data.en: No one would choose a friendless existence on condition of having all the other things in the world.

data.author: Aristotle
data.en: Wishing to be friends is quick work, but friendship is a slow ripening fruit.

data.author: Aristotle
data.en: A statement is persuasive and credible either because it is directly self-evident or because it appears to be proved from other statements that are so.

data.author: Aristotle
data.en: The eyes of some persons are large, others small, and others of a moderate size; the last-mentioned are the best. And some eyes are projecting, some deep-set, and some moderate, and those which are deep-set have the most acute vision in all animals; the middle position is a sign of the best disposition.

data.author: Aristotle
data.en: Even when laws have been written down, they ought not always to remain unaltered.

data.author: Aristotle
data.en: Fear is pain arising from the anticipation of evil.

data.author: Aristotle
data.en: Wit is educated insolence.

data.author: Aristotle
data.en: It is best to rise from life as from a banquet, neither thirsty nor drunken.

data.author: Aristotle
data.en: A great city is not to be confounded with a populous one.

data.author: Aristotle
data.en: Hope is a waking dream.

data.author: Aristotle
data.en: He who can be, and therefore is, another's, and he who participates in reason enough to apprehend, but not to have, is a slave by nature.

data.author: Aristotle
data.en: The moral virtues, then, are produced in us neither by nature nor against nature. Nature, indeed, prepares in us the ground for their reception, but their complete formation is the product of habit.

data.author: Aristotle
data.en: A tyrant must put on the appearance of uncommon devotion to religion. Subjects are less apprehensive of illegal treatment from a ruler whom they consider god-fearing and pious. On the other hand, they do less easily move against him, believing that he has the gods on his side.

data.author: Aristotle
data.en: The soul never thinks without a picture.

data.author: Aristotle
data.en: Persuasion is achieved by the speaker's personal character when the speech is so spoken as to make us think him credible. We believe good men more fully and more readily than others: this is true generally whatever the question is, and absolutely true where exact certainty is impossible and opinions are divided.

data.author: Aristotle
data.en: Dignity does not consist in possessing honors, but in deserving them.

data.author: Aristotle
data.en: Whether if soul did not exist time would exist or not, is a question that may fairly be asked; for if there cannot be someone to count there cannot be anything that can be counted, so that evidently there cannot be number; for number is either what has been, or what can be, counted.

data.author: Aristotle
data.en: A sense is what has the power of receiving into itself the sensible forms of things without the matter, in the way in which a piece of wax takes on the impress of a signet-ring without the iron or gold.

data.author: Aristotle
data.en: Piety requires us to honor truth above our friends.

data.author: Aristotle
data.en: Those who educate children well are more to be honored than they who produce them; for these only gave them life, those the art of living well.

data.author: Aristotle
data.en: Suffering becomes beautiful when anyone bears great calamities with cheerfulness, not through insensibility but through greatness of mind.

data.author: Aristotle
data.en: The gods too are fond of a joke.

data.author: Aristotle
data.en: The ultimate value of life depends upon awareness and the power of contemplation rather than upon mere survival.

data.author: Aristotle
data.en: Mothers are fonder than fathers of their children because they are more certain they are their own.

data.author: Aristotle
data.en: We must no more ask whether the soul and body are one than ask whether the wax and the figure impressed on it are one.

data.author: Aristotle
data.en: The law is reason, free from passion.

data.author: Aristotle
data.en: Excellence is an art won by training and habituation. We do not act rightly because we have virtue or excellence, but we rather have those because we have acted rightly. We are what we repeatedly do. Excellence, then, is not an act but a habit.

data.author: Aristotle
data.en: If liberty and equality, as is thought by some, are chiefly to be found in democracy, they will be best attained when all persons alike share in government to the utmost.

data.author: Aristotle
data.en: Youth is easily deceived because it is quick to hope.

data.author: Aristotle
data.en: Pleasure in the job puts perfection in the work.

data.author: Aristotle
data.en: It is clearly better that property should be private, but the use of it common; and the special business of the legislator is to create in men this benevolent disposition.

data.author: Aristotle
data.en: All human actions have one or more of these seven causes: chance, nature, compulsions, habit, reason, passion, desire.

data.author: Aristotle
data.en: He who is unable to live in society, or who has no need because he is sufficient for himself, must be either a beast or a god.

data.author: Aristotle
data.en: Republics decline into democracies and democracies degenerate into despotisms.

data.author: Aristotle
data.en: The young are permanently in a state resembling intoxication.

data.author: Aristotle
data.en: I count him braver who overcomes his desires than him who conquers his enemies; for the hardest victory is over self.

data.author: Aristotle
data.en: Some animals utter a loud cry. Some are silent, and others have a voice, which in some cases may be expressed by a word; in others, it cannot. There are also noisy animals and silent animals, musical and unmusical kinds, but they are mostly noisy about the breeding season.

data.author: Aristotle
data.en: Both oligarch and tyrant mistrust the people, and therefore deprive them of their arms.

data.author: Aristotle
data.en: We live in deeds, not years; in thoughts, not breaths; in feelings, not in figures on a dial. We should count time by heart throbs. He most lives who thinks most, feels the noblest, acts the best.

data.author: Aristotle
data.en: Character may almost be called the most effective means of persuasion.

data.author: Aristotle
data.en: Courage is a mean with regard to fear and confidence.

data.author: Aristotle
data.en: Personal beauty is a greater recommendation than any letter of reference.

data.author: Aristotle
data.en: Every art and every inquiry, and similarly every action and choice, is thought to aim at some good; and for this reason the good has rightly been declared to be that at which all things aim.

data.author: Aristotle
data.en: The wise man does not expose himself needlessly to danger, since there are few things for which he cares sufficiently; but he is willing, in great crises, to give even his life - knowing that under certain conditions it is not worthwhile to live.

data.author: Aristotle
data.en: Therefore, the good of man must be the end of the science of politics.

data.author: Aristotle
data.en: Quality is not an act, it is a habit.

data.author: Aristotle
data.en: For one swallow does not make a summer, nor does one day; and so too one day, or a short time, does not make a man blessed and happy.

data.author: Aristotle
data.en: We become just by performing just action, temperate by performing temperate actions, brave by performing brave action.

data.author: Aristotle
data.en: I have gained this from philosophy: that I do without being commanded what others do only from fear of the law.

data.author: Aristotle
data.en: Misfortune shows those who are not really friends.

data.author: Aristotle
data.en: Different men seek after happiness in different ways and by different means, and so make for themselves different modes of life and forms of government.

data.author: Aristotle
data.en: Education is the best provision for old age.

data.author: Aristotle
data.en: For as the eyes of bats are to the blaze of day, so is the reason in our soul to the things which are by nature most evident of all.

data.author: Aristotle
data.en: It is Homer who has chiefly taught other poets the art of telling lies skillfully.

data.author: Aristotle
data.en: Poetry is finer and more philosophical than history; for poetry expresses the universal, and history only the particular.

data.author: Aristotle
data.en: For though we love both the truth and our friends, piety requires us to honor the truth first.

data.author: Aristotle
data.en: He who is to be a good ruler must have first been ruled.

data.author: Aristotle
data.en: All men by nature desire knowledge.

data.author: Aristotle
data.en: To attain any assured knowledge about the soul is one of the most difficult things in the world.

data.author: Aristotle
data.en: No notice is taken of a little evil, but when it increases it strikes the eye.

data.author: Aristotle
data.en: We make war that we may live in peace.

data.author: Aristotle
data.en: Of all the varieties of virtues, liberalism is the most beloved.

data.author: Aristotle
data.en: The duty of rhetoric is to deal with such matters as we deliberate upon without arts or systems to guide us, in the hearing of persons who cannot take in at a glance a complicated argument or follow a long chain of reasoning.

data.author: Aristotle
data.en: Man is by nature a political animal.

data.author: Aristotle
data.en: We praise a man who feels angry on the right grounds and against the right persons and also in the right manner at the right moment and for the right length of time.

data.author: Aristotle
data.en: The greatest virtues are those which are most useful to other persons.

data.author: Aristotle
data.en: The worst form of inequality is to try to make unequal things equal.

data.author: Aristotle
data.en: Happiness depends upon ourselves.

data.author: Aristotle
data.en: Those who excel in virtue have the best right of all to rebel, but then they are of all men the least inclined to do so.

data.author: Aristotle
data.en: Hence poetry is something more philosophic and of graver import than history, since its statements are rather of the nature of universals, whereas those of history are singulars.

data.author: Aristotle
data.en: Democracy is when the indigent, and not the men of property, are the rulers.

data.author: Aristotle
data.en: We are not angry with people we fear or respect, as long as we fear or respect them; you cannot be afraid of a person and also at the same time angry with him.

data.author: Aristotle
data.en: But if nothing but soul, or in soul mind, is qualified to count, it is impossible for there to be time unless there is soul, but only that of which time is an attribute, i.e. if change can exist without soul.

data.author: Aristotle
data.en: Nature does nothing in vain.

data.author: Aristotle
data.en: Probable impossibilities are to be preferred to improbable possibilities.

data.author: Aristotle
data.en: Bring your desires down to your present means. Increase them only when your increased means permit.

data.author: Aristotle
data.en: Temperance is a mean with regard to pleasures.

data.author: Aristotle
data.en: The least initial deviation from the truth is multiplied later a thousandfold.

data.author: Aristotle
data.en: To run away from trouble is a form of cowardice and, while it is true that the suicide braves death, he does it not for some noble object but to escape some ill.

data.author: Aristotle
data.en: My best friend is the man who in wishing me well wishes it for my sake.

data.author: Aristotle
data.en: Law is mind without reason.

data.author: Aristotle
data.en: Excellence, then, is a state concerned with choice, lying in a mean, relative to us, this being determined by reason and in the way in which the man of practical wisdom would determine it.

data.author: Aristotle
data.en: Jealousy is both reasonable and belongs to reasonable men, while envy is base and belongs to the base, for the one makes himself get good things by jealousy, while the other does not allow his neighbour to have them through envy.

data.author: Aristotle
data.en: Men are swayed more by fear than by reverence.

data.author: Aristotle
data.en: Without friends no one would choose to live, though he had all other goods.

data.author: Aristotle
data.en: It is just that we should be grateful, not only to those with whose views we may agree, but also to those who have expressed more superficial views; for these also contributed something, by developing before us the powers of thought.
